title.narrative: Support institutional capacity-building of the Governments of Thailand and Mongolia for the design of a policy framework to improve national productivity

description.narrative:
Currently, Thailand is being stuck in the ‘middle income trap’ due to a lack of labor force and capital required to convert into high value-added industries. The per-capita GDP in Thailand after reaching its peak in 2013 is now gradually declining. Particularly, as this country enters an aging society, it suffers from a lack of labor, which leads to reduction in productivity. The government of Thailand has put its utmost efforts into developing industrial development policies that stimulate SMEs' productivity and promote innovation.
Although rising as a middle-income country, Mongolia which has typical resource-based industrial structure also suffers from gradual decline of the growth potential in recent years due to the drop in international resource prices, reduction in domestic and international demand. The Mongolian government recognizes that it is urgent to diversify industrial structure and establish a manufacturing base through the development of SMEs in order to achieve sustainable growth. To this end, the government formulated and initiates the ‘national industrial policy’ based on several objectives in June 2015: avoidance of the industrial structure which is dependent on mining resources and agriculture, development of the manufacturing industry and industrial diversification.
The productivity level of Thailand and Mongolia shows a significant gap in comparison to the leading economies in the Asia-Pacific region, which is about 1/5 of Singapore, 1/4 of US, 1/3 of EU and Japan, 1/2 of Korea and Malaysia. Both countries are trying to improve productivity level to cope with the current economic challenges in front of them. In this context, this project is formulated to enhance institutional capacity of the Government of Thailand and Mongolia which is needed as basic foundations in the design of policy framework for national productivity innovation, especially at SMEs by sharing the knowledge and experiences built up in the process of initiating productivity improvement policies in advanced countries. Specifically, it will deliver training activities on the production of productivity statistics and the establishment of productivity management support system and will provide a study tour to benefit from the experiences of productivity improvement practices of a benchmark country, whose results will be able to be directly deployed in the design of a tailor-made policy framework to enhance national and SMEs’ productivity in these countries.
